alert.note: Alert for Jackson (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 27 at 1:02AM EDT until May 28 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 1245 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Jackson County, North Carolina. * WHEN...Until 1245 PM EDT Friday. * IMPACTS...Areas along the Tuckasegee River downstream from the confluence near NC 107 and NC 281 to Cullowhee to Webster to Dillsboro to Whittier will continue to see rises and Minor to Moderate flooding. Meanwhile, isolated Minor flooding will continue over the next couple of hours along the east and west forks of the Tuckasegee headwaters before these smaller streams finally begin to crest and recede. Moderate flooding is defined as significant flooding of flood-prone, low-lying areas adjacent to streams including farmland, campgrounds, greenways, parks, and boat-access areas. Additionally, some structural flooding is expected, including homes that are immediately adjacent to streams. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1248 AM EDT, Heavy rainfall had ended earlier across Jackson County, but a new round of moderate rain is entering the county and may persist for the next 1-2 hours before another lull occurs. Storm-total rainfall of 3 to 6 inches was observed across the county, with the heaviest rain across the southern third of the county over the headwaters of the Tuckasegee River. Unusually high flows continue to impact the reservoirs of the east and west forks of the Tuckasegee River and these high flows are continuing to cause significant rises along the Tuckasegee River. This is resulting in widespread Minor to isolated Moderate flooding within the valley and this flooding is expected to continue for several more hours before the floodwave moves downstream into Swain County and conditions gradually improve by Friday morning. However, since the original flash flood threat has ended, the Flash Flood Warning has been cancelled and replaced with a Flood Warning. This does not mean significant flood threat has ended, rather that the flooding has persisted for several hours past the causative heavy rain event, allowing smaller streams to crest and recede and focusing all significant flood concerns along the mainstem Tuckasegee River. Several vulnerable mobile homes along Fred Smith Road near the community of Tuckasegee reported floodwaters 3-4 feet deep and evacuations were needed this evening. A campground along Tunnel Mountain Rd is currently experiencing significant inundation as well. Additional impacts are likely to develop downstream including additional significant flooding. Residents and other persons near the Tuckasegee River need to be prepared to heed any evacuation orders or other guidance from Jackson County Emergency Management and seek higher ground if the river continues to rise. - Yet another around of additional rainfall of 1-2 inches is possible between 2am and 5am this morning before the heavy rain threat finally ends later tonight. This will prolong ongoing flooding and may cause new areas of flooding to develop. Locally heavier rainfall is possible and new Flash Flood Warnings may be needed. It will be critically important to stay weather aware and be prepared to seek higher ground if new flash flooding develops. - Some locations that will continue to experience flash flooding include... Sylva, Cherokee, Cullowhee, Webster, Dillsboro, Cashiers, Lake Glenville, Tuckasegee, Savannah, and Whittier.
info.instruction: Please heed all messages and evacuation orders from Jackson County Emergency Management officials. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Obey all barricades and find alternative routes to stay alive. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
